scenario: A political campaign increased its advertising budget by 50% in swing districts during the 2020 election. The candidate won those districts by an average margin of 2%. Polling showed a 3% boost in name recognition correlated with the ads.
counterfactual_claim: If the campaign had not increased advertising, the candidate would have lost those swing districts
label: CONDITIONAL
justification: Voting behavior is probabilistic, and the 2% margin is within typical polling error. The advertising effect, while likely positive, cannot be deterministically linked to victory. Other factors could have provided the marginal boost.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is conditional because electoral outcomes depend on many probabilistic factors. The advertising may have been influential but not necessarily decisive.
key_insight: Electoral margins within polling error make counterfactual claims about campaign effects inherently uncertain.

scenario: A city implemented a vaccination campaign that achieved 85% coverage. COVID-19 hospitalizations dropped by 70% compared to similar unvaccinated cities. Individual vaccine efficacy was estimated at 80% against severe disease.
counterfactual_claim: If the vaccination campaign had not occurred, hospitalizations would have been 70% higher
label: CONDITIONAL
justification: While vaccination clearly reduced hospitalizations, the exact counterfactual depends on assumptions about viral spread dynamics, herd immunity thresholds, and behavioral changes. The 70% figure requires modeling assumptions.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires specifying epidemiological model assumptions. Different models of disease spread and immunity would yield different counterfactual estimates.
key_insight: Probabilistic disease transmission makes precise counterfactual quantification dependent on model assumptions.

scenario: A city increased police foot patrols by 30% in high-crime neighborhoods. Violent crime decreased by 15% over two years. Research suggests each additional patrol reduces crime probability by roughly 5% in the immediate area.
counterfactual_claim: If police patrols had not increased, violent crime would have remained at previous levels
label: CONDITIONAL
justification: Crime is influenced by many probabilistic factors. While increased patrols likely contributed to the reduction, economic conditions, social programs, and displacement effects also play roles. The counterfactual requires assumptions about these factors.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on assumptions about crime displacement, underlying trends, and the relative contribution of patrols versus other factors.
key_insight: Crime causation involves multiple probabilistic pathways that complicate counterfactual attribution.

scenario: A lottery-based scholarship program awarded full tuition to 500 randomly selected low-income students. Graduation rates for recipients were 75% compared to 45% for non-recipients from the same applicant pool.
counterfactual_claim: If the scholarship recipients had not received funding, their graduation rate would have been 45%
label: VALID
justification: The lottery-based assignment creates a natural experiment. Random selection ensures recipients and non-recipients were statistically equivalent, making the graduation rate difference attributable to the scholarship.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid because the lottery design creates a credible comparison group. The graduation rate difference reflects the causal effect of the scholarship.
key_insight: Randomized assignment provides strong counterfactual validity even for probabilistic outcomes.

scenario: A job training program served 1,000 unemployed workers. After six months, 60% of participants found employment compared to 40% of similar non-participants. The local unemployment rate was declining generally during this period.
counterfactual_claim: If the job training had not been offered, participant employment would have been 40%
label: INVALID
justification: Program participants self-selected, likely differing in motivation and job-readiness from non-participants. The declining unemployment rate means some would have found jobs anyway. Selection bias invalidates the simple counterfactual comparison.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is invalid due to selection bias. Participants who chose to enroll likely differed systematically from non-participants, confounding the comparison.
key_insight: Self-selection into programs creates bias that invalidates naive counterfactual comparisons.

scenario: A study found that children who attended high-quality preschool had 25% higher lifetime earnings than peers who did not. The preschool program was offered to all families in a specific zip code, with 70% participation.
counterfactual_claim: If preschool attendees had not participated, they would have earned 25% less over their lifetimes
label: CONDITIONAL
justification: The 30% who did not participate may differ systematically from participants in parental involvement, which itself affects earnings. The counterfactual requires assumptions about whether these differences would persist.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether non-participation was random or reflected family characteristics that independently affect earnings.
key_insight: Voluntary program participation creates selection effects that complicate lifetime outcome counterfactuals.

scenario: A state raised the legal drinking age from 18 to 21. Alcohol-related traffic fatalities among 18-20 year olds dropped by 40%. Surveys showed that 70% of the age group complied with the new law.
counterfactual_claim: If the drinking age had remained at 18, fatalities would have stayed at previous levels
label: VALID
justification: The policy change directly restricted legal access to alcohol for the affected age group, and the reduction in fatalities is consistent with the mechanism of reduced drinking. Even partial compliance produced significant effects.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is valid because the mechanism linking drinking age to access to youth fatalities is well-established and the observed effect is consistent with the policy change.
key_insight: Policy changes affecting access to risky behaviors can have valid counterfactual effects even with imperfect compliance.

scenario: A retirement savings plan changed its default from opt-in to opt-out enrollment. Participation rates increased from 40% to 85%. Employee surveys showed most new participants were unaware the default had changed.
counterfactual_claim: If the default had remained opt-in, participation would have stayed at 40%
label: CONDITIONAL
justification: While the default change clearly increased participation, participation might have increased anyway as employees aged and thought more about retirement. The counterfactual requires assumptions about baseline trends in savings behavior.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual depends on whether participation would have increased naturally over time due to life-cycle effects or economic conditions.
key_insight: Nudge effects must be separated from underlying behavioral trends for counterfactual validity.

scenario: A country introduced generous parental leave policies in 2015. The fertility rate increased from 1.6 to 1.9 children per woman over five years. Similar countries without such policies saw stable or declining rates.
counterfactual_claim: If parental leave had not been expanded, fertility would have remained at 1.6
label: CONDITIONAL
justification: Fertility decisions involve complex personal factors. While the policy likely contributed, other factors like economic optimism or cultural shifts could also explain part of the increase. Cross-country comparison is imperfect due to other differences.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual requires assumptions about what other factors might have affected fertility decisions during this period.
key_insight: Fertility as a probabilistic outcome of many factors makes policy attribution challenging.

scenario: A sugar tax of 20% was implemented on sweetened beverages. Consumption dropped by 25% in the first year, and diabetes diagnoses fell by 5% over three years. Price elasticity studies predicted a 15-20% consumption reduction.
counterfactual_claim: If the sugar tax had not been implemented, diabetes rates would have continued rising
label: CONDITIONAL
justification: While the tax reduced consumption as predicted, the link from reduced consumption to diabetes diagnoses involves time lags and multiple health factors. The 5% reduction could reflect other dietary changes or awareness effects.
wise_refusal: This counterfactual is conditional because the pathway from tax to diabetes involves intermediate steps with their own probabilistic relationships.
key_insight: Long causal chains from policy to health outcomes involve cumulative uncertainty.
